feature.name: daily wage calculator
feature.description: The daily wage calculator is a payroll feature that automatically computes daily pay deductions for employees taking unpaid leave. It divides an employee's total salary (basic + allowance) by the number of actual working days in the month to determine the per-day pay rate. The calculator accounts for leave policy variations (calendar days vs. working days) and automatically deducts public holidays from working day counts to ensure accurate salary reductions. Once an unpaid leave request is approved, the system generates an automatic pay deduction reflected on the payroll table.

source_articles_index.title: How is daily pay calculated
source_articles_index.article_summary: This article explains how daily pay is calculated for unpaid leave deductions. It defines the core formula (Salary / Actual Working Days), clarifies the distinction between calendar days and working days leave policies, and details how public holidays must be deducted from working days to arrive at the actual working days used in the calculation. The article provides a concrete example showing how 2 public holidays reduce the calculation basis from 22 working days to 20 days.

source_articles_index.title: Introduction to daily wage calculator
source_articles_index.article_summary: Introduces the Daily Wage Calculator feature, explaining how it provides flexible customization options for calculating daily wages using three calculation bases (calendar days, working days, custom days) and multiple salary component options. Describes how the calculator impacts salary proration, leave encashment, and unpaid leave deductions. Details the distinctions between calculation bases and notes that UAE and KSA companies typically use 30 custom days to comply with labor law.

source_articles_index.title: Salary Proration
source_articles_index.article_summary: Explains how Super admins can update salary proration in the Daily Wage Calculator by selecting calculation bases (custom days, calendar days, or working days) via Settings > Payroll > Daily wage calculation. Changes affect all active payroll amounts. When payroll month is open with existing prorated transactions, Super admin must reject those transactions before saving new proration settings.

Adjust and calculate an employee's salary proportionally based on the actual days worked, affecting their first salary and end-of-service settlement through selection of calculation bases (custom days, calendar days, or working days).

procedures.procedure_name: Calculate Daily Pay for Unpaid Leave Deduction
procedures.when_to_use: When an unpaid leave request has been approved and daily pay deduction needs to be calculated and applied to payroll
steps: Receive and approve unpaid leave request
Identify the leave policy type (calendar days or working days)
Determine the baseline number of days (e.g., 30 calendar days or 22 working days)
Identify all public holidays falling within the month
Subtract public holidays from baseline days to calculate actual working days
Apply formula: Daily Pay = Salary Amount / Actual Working Days
Automatic pay deduction is created and reflected on payroll table

procedures.when_to_use: When setting up payroll calculation methodology or when organizational policies or labor law requirements change.
steps: Navigate to Settings → Payroll → Daily Wage Calculation
Select calculation base from three options: calendar days, working days, or custom days
Choose salary components to include in calculation (basic salary, basic salary plus allowances, or allowances only)
Apply configuration; system will use these settings for salary proration, leave encashment, and unpaid leave deduction calculations

procedures.when_to_use: When adjusting how employee salaries are prorated based on days worked, or when changing the calculation basis for salary proration
steps: Navigate to Settings > Payroll > Daily wage calculation
Select the required calculation basis: custom days, calendar days, or working days
If payroll month is open with existing prorated salary transactions, reject those transactions before saving the new proration settings

rules_limitations_constraints.rule: Daily pay is calculated by dividing total salary (Basic + Allowance) by the number of actual working days in the month ; Leave policy can follow either calendar days (e.g., 30 days) or working days (e.g., 22 days) methodology ; Public holidays falling in the month must be deducted from the working days to arrive at actual working days ; Pay deduction is automatically created only upon approval of unpaid leave request

Calendar days calculation uses actual number of days in each month (31 for January, 28 for February, etc.); working days calculation excludes weekends and public holidays as defined in company's public holiday calendar; custom days allows fixed day count per month regardless of actual calendar. ; Most companies in UAE and KSA use 30 custom days to comply with labor law requirements that define a month as 30 days. ; Only Superadmin, Payroll table managers, or transaction processors can select the calculation base for daily wage.

Changes to salary proration settings will affect all active (unpaid) amounts in the payroll table immediately upon saving ; When payroll month is open and prorated salary transactions are submitted for one or multiple employees, the Super admin must reject the transactions with prorated salaries before saving new salary proration changes

edge_cases_warnings.edge_case_or_warning: Public holidays must be carefully identified and subtracted from working days; failure to account for holidays results in incorrect daily pay calculation and overstated deductions ; When leave policy is based on working days (e.g., 22 days), public holidays are deducted from this baseline; for example, 2 public holidays reduce the calculation basis from 22 to 20 days

Calendar days calculation will vary month-to-month based on actual calendar (January has 31 days, February has 28 days), which directly impacts daily wage rate calculations and resulting salary proration and leave encashment amounts. ; Different calculation bases (calendar days vs. working days vs. custom days) will produce different daily wage rates and therefore different final amounts for salary proration, leave encashment, and unpaid leave deductions.
When payroll month is open with existing prorated salary transactions, Super admin must manually reject and resave transactions after updating salary proration settings to ensure consistency

The daily wage calculator is a payroll feature that automatically computes daily pay deductions for employees taking unpaid leave. It divides an employee's total salary (basic + allowance) by the number of actual working days in the month to determine the per-day pay rate. The calculator accounts for leave policy variations (calendar days vs. working days) and automatically deducts public holidays from working day counts to ensure accurate salary reductions. Once an unpaid leave request is approved, the system generates an automatic pay deduction reflected on the payroll table.
